se.lypson.common
Class MultiTapKeypad

java.lang.Object
  se.lypson.common.MultiTapKeypad

public class MultiTapKeypad
extends java.lang.Object

A class for interpreting input of the keys 0-9, * and #, the typical keys availableon a mobile phone, as character input.

Author:
Tobias Persson

Constructor Detail

MultiTapKeypad

public MultiTapKeypad()
Creates a new instance of MultiTapKeypad

Method Detail

getInputMode

public int getInputMode()
Gets the current input mode.

Returns:
The current input mode - one of MODE_LOWERCASE, MODE_NEXT_UPPERCASE, MODE_UPPERCASE or MODE_DIGITS.

setInputMode

public void setInputMode(int inputMode)
Sets the current input mode.

Parameters:
inputMode - the new current input mode - one of MODE_LOWERCASE, MODE_NEXT_UPPERCASE, MODE_UPPERCASE or MODE_DIGITS.

switchInputMode

public int switchInputMode()
Cyclically switches the input mode to the next available input mode.

Returns:
The new input mode - one of MODE_LOWERCASE, MODE_NEXT_UPPERCASE, MODE_UPPERCASE or MODE_DIGITS.

registerInput

public boolean registerInput(int keyCode)
Registers a new key input.

Parameters:
keyCode - the keyCode for the key pressed. Must be one of Canvas.KEY_NUM0-Canvas.KEY_NUM9 or Canvas.KEY_POUND.
Returns:
true if this key input results in a new character, false if this key input results in a character that should replace the old character.

getChar

public char getChar()
             throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
Gets the last character that has been put in.

Returns:
The last character that was put in.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalStateException - thrown when no input has been registered after construction or after executing resetInput().

resetInput

public void resetInput()
Resets the input, forcing the next key pressed to be considered a new key pressed. The input mode is not affected. Calling getChar() after this method without a call to registerInput(int) in between will result in getChar throwing an exception.
